item.title: George Floyd death: Arrested cop's wife leaves him in shock statement
item.description:
The "devastated" wife of the police officer arrested and charged over George Floyd's death has publicly announced that she is leaving him immediately.
A statement issued to media by Derek Chauvin's wife's ...

item.title: Target: Elimination – experts rate NZ's response in Covid-19 battle
item.description: It's been more than 80 days since New Zealand's first case of Covid-19 was announced. Our Government has been globally lauded for squashing the virus – but did it get everything right? Science reporter ...
item.author: newsfeeds@nzherald.co.nz

enclosure.url: https://media.nzherald.co.nz/webcontent/image/jpg/202021/300320NZHBPCOVID19_011_70x70.jpg?media_subtype_id=16|caption=A health worker stops a car in Kirkbride Road on March 30. Experts are generally happy with the way New Zealand responded to the pandemic. Photo / Brett Phibbs

https://media.nzherald.co.nz/webcontent/image/jpg/202021/A_21112013NZHNSSIOUXSIE13_70x70.jpg?media_subtype_id=16|caption=University of Auckland microbiologist Associate Professor Siouxsie Wiles. Photo / Natalie Slade

https://media.nzherald.co.nz/webcontent/image/jpg/202021/310320POOLCOVID13_70x70.jpg?media_subtype_id=16|caption=Director-General of Health Dr Ashley Bloomfield. Photo / Hagen Hopkins/Getty Images
https://media.nzherald.co.nz/webcontent/image/jpg/202021/A_230715NZHGBSHAUN6_70x70.jpg?media_subtype_id=16|caption=University of Auckland physicist Professor Shaun Hendy. Photo / Greg Bowker

item.title: Remarkable return: Wonderful Warriors demolish Dragons
item.description:
Warriors 18 Dragons 0
It was the Kodi Nikorima show as a miracle met a fairytale at Central Coast Stadium.
The unfancied Warriors re-launched their season with a stunning 18-0 demolition job on the ...
item.author: newsfeeds@nzherald.co.nz

item.title: Contractor throws family's dead one-eyed cat in ditch
item.description:
A company contracted to dispose of dead animals on Auckland's streets are investigating after a worker threw a distraught family's dead cat in a ditch.
A Titirangi couple's perseverance to recover their ...
item.author: newsfeeds@nzherald.co.nz

enclosure.url: https://media.nzherald.co.nz/webcontent/image/jpg/202022/96748834_1689513977855464_5685872655010365440_n_70x70.jpg?media_subtype_id=16|caption=Muffin the cat died after being hit by a car in late May, 2020, in Titirangi.

https://media.nzherald.co.nz/webcontent/image/jpg/202022/26904662_1055133237960211_8179260192261924038_n_70x70.jpg?media_subtype_id=16|caption=Muffin's owners say they witnessed "multiple bones including a full rib cage suspected to be from a domestic dog" in the ditch where their pet was recovered from.

https://media.nzherald.co.nz/webcontent/image/jpg/202022/99421173_1704316533041875_2163842315142037504_o_70x70.jpg?media_subtype_id=16|caption=Muffin the cat, owned by a Titirangi couple, only had one eye and suffered an undignified disposal by a council contractor after her death last week.
